natural problem: Find the domain of the function $f(x) = \tan(\arccos(x^2)).$
natural solution: For $\arccos (x^2)$ to be defined, we must have $-1 \le x^2 \le 1,$ which is satisfied only for $-1 \le x \le 1.$  Then $\arccos (x^2)$ will always return an angle between 0 and $\frac{\pi}{2}.$  Then $\tan (\arccos(x^2))$ is defined, unless $\arccos(x^2) = \frac{\pi}{2}.$  This occurs only when $x = 0.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = tan (arccos (x powr 2))"
shows  "f x is_defined_on (-1, 0) \<union> (0, 1)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the domain of the function $f(x) = \tan(\arccos(x^2)).$ The final Answer is [-1,0) \cup (0,1]
 ### Proof
 For $\arccos (x^2)$ to be defined, we must have $-1 \le x^2 \le 1,$ which is satisfied only for $-1 \le x \le 1.$  Then $\arccos (x^2)$ will always return an angle between 0 and $\frac{\pi}{2}.$  Then $\tan (\arccos(x^2))$ is defined, unless $\arccos(x^2) = \frac{\pi}{2}.$  This occurs only when $x = 0.$
 Therefore, the domain of $f(x)$ is $\boxed{[-1,0) \cup (0,1]}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = tan (arccos (x powr 2))"
shows  "f x is_defined_on (-1, 0) \<union> (0, 1)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: The function $f(x) = \tan(\arccos(x^2))$ is defined on the intervals $(-1, 0)$ and $(0, 1)$.

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. -1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 1 \<and> x \<noteq> 0 \<longrightarrow> f x = tan (arccos (x powr 2))"
shows  "DOMAIN f = {x. -1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 1 \<and> x \<noteq> 0}"

a_3.formal problem:
definition domain :: "real set"
where "domain = {x. -1 ≤ x ∧ x < 0} ∪ {x. 0 < x ∧ x ≤ 1}"

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real ⇒ real"
assumes h0 : "∀ x. f x = tan (arccos (x powr 2))"
shows  "x ∈ domain"

 Therefore, the domain of $f(x)$ is $\boxed{[-1,0) \cup (0,1]}.$
 *)

fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = tan (arccos (x^2))"
shows  "UNIV - {0} = {x. f x = tan (arccos (x^2))}"
